Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.
Depot for Egypt : J. McGregor, Chemist.

The Hydropathic Department, which is furnished with all necessary baths and electrical apparatus, is under the care of a skillful diplomed physician, whose efficacious treatments have already rendered invaluable help to many sufferers.

div.head: OMNIA SANITAS.
div.p: Mr. Brodrick, who, questions of policy is one of the sincerest friends ever possessed by the British Army, calls attention in the "Times" to an aspect of that. Army's preparation for war which is of all others the most likely to be forgotten. If Haldane or any other War Minister should succeed in raising the department above the buffetings of political faction, we may be able in the fulness of time to behold an Army competent in its size, equipment, and training to face the uttermost of national responsibilities; but Mr. Brodrick is anxious to remind us that, unless we insist on great advances in one particular branch of administration, wo shall preserve a weakness that may easily cancel the whole of this brave efficiency. None but a madman would propose to send a force to war to-day with the weapons employed at Vittoria and Waterloo. Bnt we allow our soldiers to fight under some conditions quite as antiquated as the muzzle-loader, for, as Mr. Brodriok puts it, "the regulations of the " British service as to disease prevention "remain substantially what they were one " hundred years ago." Now, the fight which every army has to wage with disease is at least as critical and severe as that which it is called on to maintain against a human enemy. The Crimea, where 230 men per 1,000 died of disease and only 150 per 1,000 succumbed to wounds, is an old story. But South Africa is of yesterday, and its figures prove, whichever way we torn them, that warlike weapons throw an insignificant burden upon the military hospital alongside of the work with which ordinary sickness provides it. The deaths in every thousand men engaged in the Boer war were 69 from disease and 42 from wounds; 746 per 1,000 went into hospital sick, and only 34 wounded. Altogether, from first to last, 450,000 oases were passed through the hospitals owing to disease, or more than twenty times the number on whom injuries were inflicted in actual hostilities These astonishing and little-known figures throw a significant light upon the real economics of war. They show that the purely military virtues are of little avail, if we are unable to check the inroads of a far more insidious and deadly assailant than man upon our numerical strength and combatant energy. "The unopposed crossing of the Modder river lost us from typhoid Ur more man than the battle of Colenso from wounds." As between two enemies of equal calibre in numbers, courage, and armament. Omnia sanitas is the supreme principle which mast determine the award of victory.

If we are to believe Mr. Brodrick, this staring, we might almost say shrieking, lesson of the Boer War is still complacently unapplied in the training of the forces. And yet we have before as not only the deplorable results of our own sanitary incapacity in South Africa but the contrary example of what scrupulous and systematic foresight did for the Japanese in their Manchurian campaign. While the British proportion of sick to wounded was twenty to one, the ratio in Manchuria was scarcely more than four to three. Or, to put it in another light, 74 per cent of the British Army, and only 36 per cent. of the Japanese, were disabled by those conditions of war which have nothing to do with combatant weapons, but only with the facts of sanitation, and a zealous and thorough fidelity to scientific knowledge If our authorities have really failed to begin the application of these lessons to the training of the Army for its next ordeal, Mr. Brodrick's is a graver indictment than the monstrous reformers have yet been able to bring against the existing system and its directors. If military hygiene remains stationary, the greater part of our recruiting energy will go merely to crowd the field hospitals of the coming war. If oar officers are not qualified to test drinking water, if they are undistracted in the more obvious principles of camp location, then In oar rank-and file we are merely furnishing not indeed "food for cannon," bat food for hollers, dysentery, and enteric. Mr. Brodrick complains that, while the Medical Department of the Army i°, of course, proficient in these branohes of knowledge, it is withoot any means of bringing them to bear upon the commanding and executive staff. The medical officer is allowed neither the requisite help to carry out sanitation in war nor the Opportunity of educating his combatant colleagues in time of peace. And we have nothing approaching to that dose and stringent hygienic discipline of the common soldier, of which the Tokyo correspondent of the "Times" famishes so striking a description. There may be time to remedy these weaknesses before they betray ns. In the ten years between their two Manchurian (campaigns the Japanese made an advance in scientific methods which altered the whole complexion of their tables of casualties in the field and in the hospital. But it is a depressing thought that we have not yet put one foot before another on the path which leads from careless routine towards earnest and intelligent proficiency. ("Pall Mall Gazette.")

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: To-day's plague bulletin records a fatal case at Alexandria.

div.head: Cattle Plague.
div.p: Bovine typhus has made its appearance in the Sennoures district.

div.head: Scholars to form Club.
div.p: The scholars of Ras el-Tin School, Alexandria, intend to establish a club in this city.

div.head: First Crematorium in India.
div.p: The "Times of India" reports this inauguration of a crematorium for Europeans at Calcutta, this being the first crematorium established east of Suez.

div.head: The Slave Trade.
div.p: Two Sudanese males and five females, an Abyssiuian, and a Charkas woman were released from slavery during the last month by the Slave Trade Repression Department.

div.head: Conflagration at Shibin-El-Kam.
div.p: Fire broke out, on Wednesday, in a building at Shibin-Ei-Kom, and extended to the neighbouring houses of Shaira El-Kenisseh. Twenty houses were destroyed in the course of several hours. The damage has not yet been estimated.

div.head: Khedivial Decorations.
div.p: The Khedive has conferred the grade of Mirmiran on Nagib Pacha Shakour, manager of the Egyptian Enterprise and Development Company, Cairo; Leif el Nasr Pacha Mohamed, a notable of Mullawa, and Youssef Pacha Issawi, of Menoufieh. His Highness has also conferred the Muttamaiz on Moris Bey Romano, manager of the Land Bank of Egypt, Alexandria, and the Sanieh upon Khalil Bey Sabit, editor of the "Sudan Times."

div.head: Charity Concert.
div.p: With reference to the recent announcement in our columns anent the concert being organised for the benefit of the widow and five young children of the late Sergt. Major Smith, R.E., we may remind our readers that it will take place on Saturday evening next in the large dining hall of the Grand Continental Hotel, Cairo, at 9:30 p.m. From the names that have been submitted to us of those ladies and gentlemen who have very kindly come forward with songs, instrumental pieces, etc., we have no hesitation in saying that it promises to be one of the most successful concerts that have ever taken place in Cairo, and we advise all those who have not yet booked their seats to do so at once. In the event of tickets not being obtainable elsewhere, they can be procured at the doors on the evening of the entertainment. By kind permission of Major Hamilton and officers of the 1st Lancashire Fusiliers, the fine string band of the regiment will take part. A very handsome piano has been given for the concert by Mr. Vincent Granato-Mezzocapo.
Col. O. Todd, R.A.M.C., leaves cairo for Suez to-night to embarq on the R.I.M.T Dufferin for passage to Bombay.
The Grek notables of Cairo are giving a banquet at the Grand Continental Hotel, Cairo, on Sunday, to M/ Gennadis, the retiring Hellenic Diplomatic Agent, on the occasion of his departure for Athens.

div.head: FOREIGN CIGARETTE-MAKERS IN GERMANY.
GOVERNMENT'S DRASTIC MEASURE
THOUSANDS EXPELLED THE COUNTRY
div.p: London, Thursday.

The Prussian Government has given a fortnight's notice to a thousand foreign cigarette-makers to leave German territory. Two thousand have already been expelled from Berllin. It is reported that expulsions of large numbers have taken place in other towns. There would sem to be no complaint against the character of the aliens, who are described as sober, industrious, and well-behaved.

div.head: THE RISING IN THE YEMEN.
div.p: News has been received from Hodeidah denying the reported murder of Sheikh Yahys, the leader of the insurgen tribes in the Yemen. On the contrary, it is stated that he is preparing a new movement, which is causing the authorities great uneasiness. The situation is aggravated by the great discontent which prevails among the troops, in consequence of the disorganisation of the commissariat service.

div.head: REDUCTION OF POSTAGE.
div.p: With effect from the 1st July next the postage on letters exchanged between Egypt (including the Sudan) and Italy, the Italian Colonies of Erythres and Benadir, and Australia, will be reduced as follows : -
From Italy and above mentioned Colonies to Egypt and the Sudan, 15 centimes for every 15 grammes of fraction thereof.
From Egypt and the Sudan to Italy, Erythrea and Benadir Coast, 5 milliemes for every 15 grammes or fraction thereof.
From Australia to Egypt and the Sudan, 2d. for every 15 grammes or fraction thereof.
From Egypt and the Sudan to Australia, 5 milliemes for every 15 grammes or fraction thereof.

div.head: CAIRO PRINTERS' STRIKE.
div.p: The lock out of the printers on the staffs of the European newspapers in Cairo continues, and Cairo is without any of its newspapers printed in a European language, except a flysheet entitled "La Presse Associe," issued in common by all the newspapers affected by the strike. It is hoped that an agreement between masters and men will shortly be reached.
The following telegram reaches us as we are going to press:–

Journaux associes vous remercient de votre concours la reunion des delegues onvriers et des patrons a eu lieu hier. Les ouvriers presentent des exigences inacceptables. Ce matin a eu lieu la reunion des patrons qui ont vote la declaration suivante, les directeurs des journaux sont disposes a reconnaitre en principe la journee de huit heures mais les delegues ouvriers n'ayant pas admins la discussion garantie en echange, il est impossbile d'accepter en bloc les conditions imposees Dans ces conditions un accord etant impossible les directeurs insistant dans l'esprit d'une conciliation, proposent un arbitrage stop l'edprit general des oubriers suit cette communication favorable entente.
COLLALTO.
MANSE.

div.head: THE JEWS AND ZION.
div.p: The president of the Swansea Zionist Society has received the following letter from the Foreign Office, dated June 5:–

"Sir,–I am directedby Secretary Sir E. Grey to acknowledge the receipt of your further letter of the 26th ult., on the subject of the creation of an independent Jewish State in Palestine, and I am to state in reply that, while his Majesty's Government will not discourage the discussion and favourable consideration of the matter should a suitable opportunity occur, there are obviously grave difficulties in the way of carrying out the proposal, which do not depend upon the disposition of his Majesty's Government.–I am, Sir, etc, Eric . Barrington."

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner Seti sailed yesterday evening for Liverpool, via Malta, with passengers, mails, and general cargo, including 642 bales of cotton.

div.head: TRAGEDY NEAR TALA.
GRAVE OUTRAGE ON BRITISH OFFICERS.
ONE KILLED AND SEVERAL WOUNDED.
div.p: The unintelligible wire which we published yesterday from our Tala Correspondent proves to have concealed a tragedy. During the route march of the Mounted Infantry from Cairo to Alexandria an affray with fellaheen at Denshawi, near Tala, in Menoufieh province, resulted in the death of a British officers, Captain Bull, of the 6th Inniskilling Dragoons, and the infliction of severe injuries on two of his comrades.
The news became generally known in Cairo yesterday afternoon and the following official communication was made last night to Reuter's Agency:

Yesterday, during a march of British troops from Cairo to Alexandria, five officers went to a vilalge to shoot pigeons. It is understood they did so at the invitation of the omdeh. They were surrounded by the villagers, deprived of their guns, and then assaulted with nabouts. Captain Bull, of the Inniskilling Dragoos, died of his wounds in a few hours. Major Pine-Coffin, Mounted Infantry, had his arm broken, and Lietenant Smithwick, Dublin Fusiliers, was badly hurt. It is reported that some of the villagers were seriously injured in the affray, but accurate details are still wanting. A judicial investigation into the facts is being held, and the matter will be dealt with by the special tribunal which was instituted in 1895 to try cases of offences against the British Army of Occupation.
We are informed this morning that one native has been found dead near the scene of the affray. Eight are reported wounded and six have been identified by the wounded officers and arrested.

The judicial investigation now proceeding is being conducted for the Ministry of Justice by the Chibin-el-Kom Parquet, while the Ministry of the Interior is represented on the spot by the Moudir of Menoufieh and Mr. Moberly, Inspector to the Ministry, with the Mamour of Tala Markaz and other local officials.

Of the details and cause of the affray nothing appears to be officially known. According to one account, the officers left the open country, where they had been shooting, and proceeded too near the village, where some tibu was accidentally set on fire and the fella-heen thereupon attacked the party.

According to another version, a woman was accidentally injured, but it is believed in official circles that the injury, if any, was inflcted during the scuffle that followed the attempt of the fellaheen to disarm the officers, in which shots were undoubtedly fired, but that injury to a woman caused the affray if absolutely denied.

The special Court which will try the case is composed of the Minister of Justice, the Judicial Adviser, and one of the Khedivial Counsellors, but as Sir Malcolm McIlwraith is leaving for England on Monday, it is expected that Mr. Hayter will be the senior British member of the Court. The role of Deputy Judge Advocate General will be filled by Coone Cuthbert, A.A.B. to the Army of Occupation.

One result of this tragic incident will be the prohibition of pigeon shooting on the part of British officers and officials. Several unpleasant incidents, far inferior in gravity to this last, but highly disagreeable none the less, have been caused by this in the past.

Capt. Seymour Clark-Bull was born April 28, 1875. He became a 2nd lieutenant of the (6th) Inniskilling Dragoons in October, 1899, and in June 1900, was promoted lieutenant. It was only on the 12th April last that he was raised to the rank of the captain. Captain Bull saw a great deal of active service in the South African war during 1900-1902, took part in the operations in the Orange Free State in 1900, including the actions of Vet River and Zand River, and the operations in the Transvaal in May and June 1900, including the actions near Johannesburg and Pretoria, and the famous Diamond Hill engagement of the 11th and 12th June of that year. From July to the end of Nvoermber he was in the Trasvaal and Orange River Colony, and on the conclusion of peace he received the Queen's South African Medal with four clasps.

We have received no further news as to the progress of the injured officers, who are under the charge of Captain Bostock, R.A.M.C. It is believed at Headquarters that there is no ground for apprehension as to their condition.

div.head: OTHER ACCOUNTS.
div.p: Our Tala Correspondent writes under date of Wednesday:–The Markaz authorities have been informed telephonically from Kamslreesh, a villlage near Tala, that four British Mounted Infantry officers and a British medical officer have been dangerously shot while engaged in shooting pigeons. The party are said to have left their tents, which they pitched at Kamsheesh, and gone to Sirsina, on the opposite side.
An old woman was shot dead and the sheikh ghaffir was dangerously wounded.
The Mamour, with the medical officer of the Markaz, rode off to the scene of the tragedy, where the Parquet is engaged in an enquiry.

div.head: (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT)
div.p: Chilrn-el-Kom, Thursday,

About three p.m. yesterday a fire broke out in a street near the station at Chibin-el-Kom, and qaiokly spread over several houses. The Mamour, with his usual promptitude, was quickly on the spot with the looal fire engine. In half an hour it was apparent that there was going to be a big blare, and the Menouf engine came by rail to assist. A feature of the fire was the sight of Moberly Bey, Inspector of the Interior, directing affairs ina shirt and trousers, looking like a ship's fireman and doing the work of ten ordinary men.

In the midst of all the excitement news arrived by telephone from a village near Tala that there was trouble between some British soldiers and some Datives, so the moment the fire was under control (about 6 p.m.) Moberly Bey and the Moudir and the Mamonr set out for the affeoted distriot. They have not yet returned, but the following is the account carrent in Chibin :

140 Moonted Infantry were proceeding by canal from Cairo to Alexandria. When near Tala foor officers left the company and proceeded twelve miles over the fields shooting the pigeons and doves of the fellaheen in epite of native pretests. In addition to stealing ? these doves, and pigeons the officers, by the discharge of fchehr gone* set fire ,to some corn piled in the fielda and furthermore carelessly shot and killed a native woman. The ghaffirs came to take the officers bat the latter shot and badly woanded the sheikh of ghaffirs. Then the natives t>9oame outraged and setting on the officers with nabonts, heat one to death and badly woanded the others.
I cannot guarantee that the above is a correct version of the inoident, hat it is the story which is being retailed here among the natives.
The following details of the incident are published by the "Mokattam"

A Mounted Infantry detachment of the Army of Occupation left Criro on Wednesday to march down to Alexandria. Oa their arrival at Tala Markaz, Menoufieh, the troops camped at Danahawi, a village in that Markaz, for the nigty. Five officers were entertained by some ot the native notables there, who iuvited them to go pigeon-shooting at 5 p.m, which they accepted.

A namber of the natives objected to the officers shooting, as they pretended that their stores might he barned, and in the course ot the discussion which ensued, they attacked the officers with nabonts, killing one of them, Captain Ball, and severely wounding Major Pine-Coffin and Lieutenant Smithwick. They then set a corn store on fire.
A detachment [of the troops promptly came to the officers' help, and after quelling the disorder conveyed the woanded to oamp.

An attempt was made to take away the major's rifle, bat in the souffle the weapon, whieli was loaded for pigeon shooting, went off ftndta native woman was killed by the shot. The Moudir, the Chief of the Parqaet, and other authorities immediately appeared on the scope and an inquiry was opened into the cause of the outrage.

div.head: FUNERAL OF VICTIM
div.p: The funeral of the late Captain Bull will take place at the British Cemetery, Cairo, at 6.15 o'clock this evening.

div.head: THE BRITISH GARRISON.
div.p: Dealing with the recall of the 4th Battalion Worcestershire Regiment from Alexandria to Malta, the "Globe" says :—

We are bound to assume that Lord Cromer was* duly advised of this coming retreat, but we gravely question whether he would have conjselled it without Downing-street pressure. Oar, scepticism rests on substantial grounds; unless private information counts for nothing, it was not the Turkish intrusion into Egyptian territory alone that moved oar Government to augment the British garrison. Thepre was also some degree of unrest among the native troops, and this stirring of military discontent was secretly aided by the proi Turkish party at Cairo and Alexandria. It was not for nothing that one British battalion disembarked at the latter port, and marohed through the streets by a cironitous ronte; Earopean residents drew their own conqlasions from that unexpected spectacle. And the anti foreigner element in th9 native population—happily it has hot scant propor- tionp-^will also draw its own conclusions front the desperate harry of the English Go verqment to diminish the expense cf controlling * Egypt, throagh the Khedive and his Ministers. To render the recall ot the rein foroements all the more inopportune, news has .just arrived of a sadden tribal revolt the Farther Sudan, not far from El Obeid, the birthplace of Mahdism. That terror began, it will he remembered, in snob

small way that the Cairo Government treated it with indifference. Bat when the False Prophet massaored several outlying Egyptian garrisons in succession, and thas acquired prestige as the Sword of Islam, there was consternation throughout Lower Egypt, and Hicks Pasha, with hi* army of impressed fellaheen, was hurried off to certain death in the w&terle^s wilderness oast of El Obeid.

div.head:
ALEXANDRIA SPORTING CLUB.
THIRD SUMMER MEETING.
div.p: The first day's raoing of the last big race meeting of the season at Alexandria took place yesterday, and wos attended with a fair amount of suet© 8. Some gcod raoing was witnessed, especially in the last race, the distanoe of 5 farlougs being run in the record time of 1.02 minate. The barsting of an irrigation, canal and the conseqoent flooding of a part of the conrso jast before the fourth race was rnn almost caused a serious aocideut. The jockeys, unaware of what had happened, plunged with their horses into what was a small lake and were badly splashed with mad, but beyond that nothing serions happened. Lonloo broke a blood vessel in this race, and his jockey, Mr. G. H. Barker, was a good deal bespattered with blood. There was not a large attendance cf the public, but betting was fairly animated. div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui a Midi et demie)
Marche calme mais assez ferme.
L'Agricole perd 1/16 a 9 5/8
La National Bank faiblit de 1/8 a 25 ½.
Les Cottou Mills se relevent de six pence a 6.
La Banque d'Athenes, gagne ¼ a 155 ½.
La Delta Land reactionne de 1/16 a 13.16.
Les Sucreries avancent de 2 francs a 24.
La Land Bank recule de 1/8 a 8 9/16.
Les Trust sont stationnaires a 1 17/32.
Les Estates cloturent a 1 5/8 en baisse de 1/32 sur hier.

La Banque d'Orient donne lieu a de nombreuses affaires aussi son cours est tres mouvements: apres avoir ouvert a 127 ¾ elle atteint 133 et cloture a 131 ¼ en hausse de 2 france 75. Il y a encore beaucoup de decourvert sur ce titre aussi a-t-on remarque ce fait bizarre queles ventes a termes se font meilleur marche qu'au comptant.
La Bourse, a la suite d'une decision prise par la Corporation des Agents de Change, restera fermee demain.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES

div.p: Le Caire, Jeudi 14 Juin.
Le Taux de l'escompte libre a Londres se maintient a 3 ½ pur cent.

Hier, au Stock Exchange, le Consolide anglais a baisse de non moins de ¼ de livre a 88 7/8. Par contre, l'Unifiee a gagne ¼ 104 ½. La National Bank, 1'Agricole, la Daira et la Delta Light sont renseignees invariees a leaurs cours precendents.
A Paris, l'action Credit Foncier Egyptien a reactionne de 2 franes a 154 et les Lots turcs 1 franc a 147.

Notre marche a ete aussi calme que celui d'hier. Toutefois, la tendance generale a ete meilleure. Il y a eu meme, par moments, quelque peu d'animation sur l'Agricole, la Banque d'Orient, les Estates et les Nungovich.

La National Bank, delaissee, a molli a 25 ½-9/16. L'Agricole a ete demandee a 9 21/32-11/16. La Cassa di Sconto s'est maintenance 210-211 l'action ancienne et 208 la nonvelle. La Banque d'Orient a progresse a 128. Quoique renseignee en baisse de 3 francs a Paris, la Banque d'Athenes a conserve icic son prix d'hier, soit 156 francs.
L'action Credit Foncier a reactionne d 2 fracs a 772; les obligations a lots nouvelles 17 1/6. La Behereta s'est raffermie a 36 1/16.
Dans le groupe des Hotels, les Nungovich out ete demandes a 15 . 3.1601/4 et L'Anglo-American Nile a 5.
Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont ete plus fermes a 3 27/32-7/8. Les Estates ont avance a 1 5/8, les Egyptian Constructions a 1 5/32, les Oasis a 1 1/8 et les Markets a 26 sb. 6.
Les Sucrereis ont faibli a 21-22 et les Salt and Soda a 20 sh. 9.

D'apres toutes les probabilites l'assemblee extraordinaire de la Corporation des agents qui se tiendra cet apres-midi votera la cessation d'affaires a la Bourse Khediviale du Caire pour les samedis pendant la duree de la saison d'ete.
Nous detachona d'une lettre de Londres, en date du 7 Juin, le passage suivant:

d'apres toutes les probabilites l'asseblee extraordinaire de la Corporation des agents qui se tiendra cet apres midi votera la cessation d'affaires a la Bourse Khediviale du Caire pour les samedis pendant la duree de la saison d'ete.
Nous detachons d'une lettre de Londres, en date du 7 Juin, le passage suivant:

"La situation monetaire continue a troubler la quietude du monde des affaires. Malgre quelques changements en mieux qui se sont produits ces temps derniers, nous en sommes preque au meme point qu'a la fin d'Avril, et le taux de l'escompte libre reate toujours a 3 ½ pour cent par suite de la menace que la Banque d'angleterre tient suspendue au'dessus de nos establishments de credit pour les ou, gagne par une trop grande confiance dans l'avenir, ilse relacheraient de leur vigilance, et accueilleraient trop facilement le papier escomptable.

div.head:
GREECE AND ROUMANIA
RUPTURE OF RELATIONS.

div.p: Greco-Roumanian relations have been finally broken off.
Russia has undertaken the proteciton of Greeks in Roumania.
(Reuter)
Relations between Greece and Roumania have been officially broken off.
(Havas)

div.head:
THE TRIPLE ALLIANCE
COUNT GOLUCHOWSKI EXPLAINS

div.p: Count Goluchowsky, replying, before the Austrian Delegation, to the attacks on the Triple Alliance, said that the Allience would only become operative in the event of on of the Allies being attacked on two sides. He denied that Austria contemplated a campaign of expansion in the Balkans.
(Reuter)

div.head:
CONGO FREE STATE
GREAT BRITAIN'S RIGHTS

div.p: HOUSE OF COMMONS - Sir E. Grey stated in reply to a question, that the rights possessed by Great Britain in the Congo Free State, seeing that treaty obligations must be obeserved, cannot be effected by the subsequent declarations of King Leopold. His letter of the 10th inst. cannot alter them.
(Reuter)

div.head:
EXPLOSION ON ATLANTIC LINER
SIX KILLED; MANY INJURED

div.p: An explosion occurred on board the liner Haverford, hewly arrived from America. Six persons were killed and many injured. A fire broke out, but has been extinguished. It is suggested that the explosion was caused by an infernal machine.
Mr. Mallik, Liberal, will opposed Mr. Lyttleton.
(Reuter)

It is expected that the House of Commons will finish the discussion on the Educaiton Bill about the 20th of July, and will rise about 3rd of August. THe autumn session will begin at the end of October.
(Reuter)
The Chamber is discussing the Government's policy. M. Jaures spoke in favor of the expropriations of mines and railway workshops. His wordrs were greeted with prolonged murmurs.
(Havas)

div.head: "THE SPHINX CLUB."
A NOVEL BANQUET
div.p: Yesterday we gave a brief account of the "Sphinx Dinner" held in London last week.
The following is from the "tribune"

For the first time in its history, ladies were admitted to the secrets of the Sphinx Club last night, when that influential combination of advertising experts marked the importance of the event with revelry.

The banqueting hall of the Hotel Cecil suggested a showroom in the Rue de la Paix. Beautiful was models displayed the latest triumphs of Parisian fashion; a juidicious blending of silken hosiery and La France bleding of silken hosiery and La France roses formed the original table decorations; the pyramids of Cleopatra's Needle were garlanded with flowers; and the imposing figure of the Sphinx, the presiding deity at these gatherings, looked quite skittish in a white ostrich boa and the newest thing in parasols.
The brethren of the Sphinx had arranged a succession of surprises for the benefit of their fair guests.

"The Sphinx," gave the chairman, Mr. John Morgan Richards, after the diners had appreciated the novel delights of a menu which began with crevettes a la cravattes and included filets de sole au Jupon Rose, and Aigrettes d'Asperges. Then the electric lights were lowered, and in a dim Egyptian atmosphere the ladies drank the toas of their host with enthusiasm. The eyes of the Sphinx gleamed greenly as the gratified deity broke the silence of the centuries, and from its inner regions replied in a fine megaphone tenor with "Oh! the girls, the lovely girls!"

div.head: CAPE-CAIRO RAILWAY
div.p: The head of the Cape to Cairo Railway is (a Capetown message reports) now at a point 360 miles to the north of Victoria Falls, and is within sixteen miles of Broken Hill. The telegraph is working to this point.

div.head: UNREST IN ABYSSINIA
div.p: The "Temps" retorts that nows from the interior of Abyssinia points to a certain unrest prevailing there. Since the death of Ras Ma- konnen, the Empress Tai-Ta has become all powerful. In connection with this, it may be mentioned that an Abyssinian woman from Tigrd, who is married to a German in Palestine, has insinuated herself into the Empress's confidence, uuder the pretext of famishing the Empress with information about Jerusalem and the Holy Places, the Empress being very pious. 1 his woman has been working on behalf of the Germans, and the reception accorded to the German and Germano-Syrian workmen is largely due to her efforts.

A telegram from Djibouti to the same journal says that 40 Germans and Syrians belonging to the German missions in Palestine have jast arrived at Shoa. They are described as expert in oertain manual trades. A second group of immigrants, led by the son of a Galla woman and a German pastor, is shortly to follow. This information as to the extension of German influence in Ethiopia is corroborated by the nows, also sent 1 y the correspondent of the "Temps," that since Ras Makonnen's dea'h the Germans have been able to recover a good deal of indirect authority at the Court of the Negus through tho medium of tho Empress Tai-Ta, who is omnipotent.

div.head: THE WOMEN OF SPAIN
div.p: In an article in the "Nineteenth Century" "The Joys of Spain," Mr. Austin Harrison gives an account of the women of Spain that at present should interest English readers. After remarking that Spain is noted for the beauty of the women, he says: And what women more adorable than those of Spain, so proud, so simple, so radiantly feminine ? As a type the Spanish woman of the South is unique. 'L'Andalouse," who does not know Musset's tribute to her? She is small and slender, exquisitely proportioned, with tiny, bnt beautifully shaped hands and feet. Her head, poised proudly on a torso of olassioal symmetry, is small,and her hair is black and orispofthe bloisa small tint peculiar to the raven. Her face is oval, such as Raskin admired, finely chiselled, frank and childish ; her lips are full, red and pouting ; and her nose is slightly aquiline, hill nervous, qaiveriug nostrils. Her eyes are the mirror of her soal; almond shaped, somewhat like a Circassian woman's dark, lustrous, pensive, and passionate; now flashing like open globes of fire, now dreamily closing as if in sadness. Her laughter is ever on the surface, merry, rippling, infeotious, but her tears are never far distant too. Her grace of carriage and deportment is the glory of her race. In her white lace shawl and the flowers of Spain in her hair Bhe is quite irresistible, yet no prouder oreature exists, nor less coquettish a natare. Her love consumes her, and she would no more smoke a cigarette thin she woald play hockey or golf. She is simple as a bird, wayward and captious as a ohild • siuoere, for Bhe does not know what it is to be insincere. If she oannot read and write much, she can dacoe as no other woman can. When she loves she will die for you, but when she hates she will slay you with a glance as keen as any dagger.

The Spanish woman has no Greek. She blooms and withers like a wild flower. At an age when most girls in England are in the schoolroom the Spanish girl is already a woman. From childhood upwards she possesses a novio, or suitor, for her hand. It is a Spanish institution. The hidalgo courts his Dnloinea to-day as he did of old ; with twang of gaitar singing or sighing to his novia-elect under lattioed window or more favourable balcony, or whispering softly to her as she rises from mass, or cooing behind her &s she walks abroad. But she is ever demure, ooy, and elasive. Kisses are no cheap commodities in Spain. No love so proud as a Spanish girl's. No courting more ardent or assiduous than a young Spaniard's.'

Oriental usage with regard to women still prevails in Spain, where there are no suffra-! gettes, and no problems of sex. Even in society in Madrid men do not pay afternoon calls on married women, the chief form of entertainment being the evening party, or tertulia. The joalonsy of Spaniards of both sexes is notorious, The Eastern habit of seolading their women is still prevalent among most Spaniards. Hence the illiteracy of the women, the tiresome to*- mality of Spanish functions, the conventionality of society manners.

div.head: NEMI BRONZES FOR ROME
div.p: The National Maseum in the Baths of Diocletian has, the "Tribune" states, received a magnificent addition in the old Roman bronzes submerged in the Lake of Nemi for nearly 2,COO years' and brought to the surface in October 1895. Theie have been placed in a small upper room, which has just been opened to the pablic. Most of the exhibits are ornaments taken from the two Tiberian ships which it is hoped one day to raise from the depths of the lake. Chief in importance is a splendid Medusa. A strongly-modelled arm and hand in the true archaic style is also of extreme interest, while the lion, hyena, and wolf heads, with rings pendant, are wonderful specimens of their kind. Some remains of the old timber work, thickly; studded with giant nails, are also inoladed j in the collection. Signor Borghi, to whose enterprise the recovery of these gems of ancient art is due, was offered £12,000 for the ; collection by the New York Museum. The provisoes of the Pacoa law, however, stood in the way of exportation, and the whole of the objects were acquired by the Italian nation for £5,C4Q.

div.head: MERCHANTMEN AND THE NAVEL MANEUVRES
div.p: A number of Liverpool steamers are to take part in the naval manoeuvres. The Admiralty have agreed to indemnify owners for any loss arising out of delay or damage consequent on complying with the orders of naval officers. It is anticipated that in all 4C0 vessels will take part in these movements, which will extend from Great Britain to Gibraltar and to the South Atlantio. Oatward-bonnd merchantmen will call at Milford Haven or Falmouth and the homeward-bound at Gibraltar. From these ports they will make the passage in company with other vessels or otherwise as may be deemed expedient by the senior naval officer. They may be despatched in groups of twelve or less. For the ooaling of tho fleet at sea about thirty steamers have been chartered, and about /100,000 tons of coal purchased.

div.head: THE STATE BANK OF MOROCCO
THE STATUES COMPLETED.
div.p: The International Committee charged to draw up the statutes of the State Bank cf Morocco has terminated its labours. M. Pallain, the president, last week in Paris exchanged very cordial speeches with Herr Fischal, the German delegate. Herr Fischal, in the name of his colleagues, thanked M. Pallain for his graoeful hospitality, his courtoey, and impartiality. He wa9 pleased that Paris had been seleoted as the place of meeting of the Council of the Administration of the Bank.

div.head: EGYPTIAN MINES EXPLORATION
div.p: Mr. C. J. Alford has furnished the following summary of the monfh's operations.
Atallah Minb — (Central Egypt Co.)— May 26th—Main Shaft down to 205 feet in granite—Permanent head-gear completed and will shortly be in working order when sinking will be mnch accelerated.

Semna Mine — (Fatira Co.) —May 25th— Main Shaft, First Level E. 59 feet, last 15 feet vein averaged 49 inches wide and 9.7 dwts gold per ton. First Level W 72 feet, last 24 feet vein averaged 30 inohes wide and 13.2 dwts gold per ton. Main Winze at 15ft. W of Main Shaft cross-oat down to 6 feet on veia below First Level No. 1 Shaft First Level W 176 feet, last 16 feet vein averaged 27 inches wide and 31.9 dwts gold per ton. No. 3 Shaft First Level E 140 feet, last 20 feet vein averaged 60 inches wide and 15.5 dwts gold per ton

div.head: AMERICA'S AFRICAN TRADE
div.p: A bul'etin of the Department of Commerce and Labour announoes that the trade of the United States with Afrioa in the fiscal year 1905 aggregated about £6,C00,000, of which £2,266,600 was in imports and the remainder in exports. The trade with Africa amounted to £10,200,000 in 1903, having risen 'from £6,100,000 in 1900. The decrease in exports to Africa is held to be a reflection of the general reduotiou in imports into that conti* nent since 1903.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA SPORTING CLUB.
div.p: LAST NIGHT'S LOTTERIES.
The lotteries in connection with this afternoon's racing took place at the Khedivial Club yesterday evening, when the following prices were realised, in Egyptian shillings:--
SUMMER PLATE. –Roland, 75 ; Lahek, 180 ; Radium, 90 ; Suleik and Au Revoir, 155 ; Siham, 30 ; Kara Slan, 260.
IBRAHIMIEH HANDICAP. –Viking, 120 ; Temsah, 30 ; Kamboula II. and Nadium, 200 ; Aeolus, 40 ; Loulou, 220 ; Sattam, 80 ; The Bard, 25 ; Miassar and Abou Arkoub, 300.
ST. LEGER STAKES –Fadghan, 300 ; Mabsout, 90 ; Sans Pareil, 40 ; Caprice, 85 ; Chendi, 70 ; Roland, 150 ; Jupiter, 300.
ENCOURAGEMENT STAKES. –Gribiche, Ulema, and Brown Boy, 140 ; Aurelius, 220 ; Bonus, 40 ; Riado, 300.

div.head: KHEDIVAL YACHT CLUB.
div.p: The wind was light from the N.W. and the Nanine was the last boat that was expected to win in Class I. This boat seems to be handled so much better than others, which makes the task of handicapping on results so difficult.
The new boat Ram Seas, in Class II., did not at all realize the expectations ofher designer, but she still has a future before her.
